posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: My team just got a new battery analyzer/discharger and I was wanting to know what we need to look at to determine the quality of our batteries.

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

posts.cooked:
We generally look at internal resistance, I think the “good” range for us is anywhere from 0.018 to 0.022, with anywhere over 0.03 being bad. We also just take out any of the highest 4 resistances each year.

It’s also good to look at the charge when your charger says its full, it should be close to 130%, and anything less than around 100% is considered bad for us

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
There’s some good info on the CBA product page.

Start with the battery fully charged.  Set it to discharge at the max (7.5 A) down to 10.5V.  Record the total energy, and also look at the voltage graph and make sure it doesn’t have a sudden drop of 1.5 to 2V in the middle of the discharge because that indicates a bad cell.  It generally takes about 90 minutes for a full test.

Grade your batteries by total energy delivered over the test.

posts.name: Skye Leake

posts.name: Michael Anderson
posts.cooked:
Starting a new thread on this topic.

Testing methods we use to date: BD250 discharger, cold crank amp tester (carbon pile load tester) and battery beak.

We rely primarily on the BD250 to determine the capacity and health of our batteries. After formatting the batteries appropriately, we standardize our BD250 testing at 20 A to a terminating voltage of 10.8. We test all batteries before competition and rank them for use based on the measured capacity.

We rely on the battery beak for testing at comp. Quick and easy.

We have not found a good use for the cold crank testing. We’ve looked for correlations between the cold crank amp test results with BD250 capacity results and not found any correlations.   Any suggestions?  Comments welcome.

Even with the above approach, we infrequently  experience brown-out conditions during competition.  At this point we are trying to determine whether the brown out is due to the battery capabilities, or whether the bot’s demands exceed the battery’s capabilities.  Therefore I am posting the following questions for consideration.

First, any flaws or recommendations with the above approach?

First, any flaws or recommendations with the above approach?

Wondering whether anyone has developed a way to measure the load on the battery during comp.  For example, logging the current draw from the battery during comp, find the area under the current vs time curve for that particular competition and using this as a method to measure total load on that battery during that match.

Wondering whether anyone has developed a way to measure the load on the battery during comp.  For example, logging the current draw from the battery during comp, find the area under the current vs time curve for that particular competition and using this as a method to measure total load on that battery during that match.

We have no way to test the batteries in a competition-like condition.  Has anyone ever developed a program that cycles the bot through a standardized set of motions and operations to a predetermined cutoff voltage, and used the time to that cutoff voltage to rank the battery capability?  This may be overkill, but the concept is one that is interesting to toy around with.

We have no way to test the batteries in a competition-like condition.  Has anyone ever developed a program that cycles the bot through a standardized set of motions and operations to a predetermined cutoff voltage, and used the time to that cutoff voltage to rank the battery capability?  This may be overkill, but the concept is one that is interesting to toy around with.

Appreciate the ensuing comments, enjoying the forum

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
MJA:

Wondering whether anyone has developed a way to measure the load on the battery during comp. For example, logging the current draw from the battery during comp, find the area under the current vs time curve for that particular competition and using this as a method to measure total load on that battery during that match.

The driver station logs will tell you the total energy in KJ during the match, in the same area where you view the voltage and current logs.

posts.cooked:

We have no way to test the batteries in a competition-like condition. Has anyone ever developed a program that cycles the bot through a standardized set of motions and operations to a predetermined cutoff voltage, and used the time to that cutoff voltage to rank the battery capability? This may be overkill, but the concept is one that is interesting to toy around with.

You may find this paper interesting.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: A cold crank test (100 Amps or more for 10 seconds) will positively identify a failed cell.  Failed cells will NOT show up on a Battery Beak, but will show up on a capacity test.  Just after a lot of waiting…

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I prefer to test at 50 Amps (the rating for the SB50) to better simulate actual use and to pull down the test time.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
That’s the Hot-Plug or wire-to-board continuous rating.

120A continuous for wire-to-wire and NOT hot-plugging (breaker OFF nominal operation).

And higher than that for intermittent loads (electrical engineering is just one big thermal problem really…how hot for how long?) - and is what I would really classify our robot use case as.

image 1047×940 180 KB

image 1047×940 180 KB

image 1047×940 180 KB

But back on the topic of battery testing itself - We are doing 70A for annual capacity testing with an iCharger458 Duo instead of the BD testers. Seems like a reasonable approximation of a low-medium robot electrical load. I’d like 100A to make the later analysis and math simple but didn’t see a battery capacity tester off-the-shelf that could do that without modification or making my own - which although would be fun I don’t have time for lol.

If a battery is suspect mid-season that would be a reason to capacity re-test, but this is our first year more thoroughly testing so that situation hasn’t arisen yet.

Debating periodic battery-beak measurements during comp, as well as figuring out how to reliably log the match power data to then combine with all other data sources and have a “realtime” health report of the batteries and watch them change over time.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Making my own, I have to say that 50 Amps is a lotta heat Its a huge heat sink with a solid fan on it…

We do the exact same thing. Same measurements, same internal resistance, same charge percent. Our brownout issues went down a lot. Before we tested our batteries, we would accidently grab batteries that just got used or were bad. Highly recommend the advice @FinIce gave.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: We are getting close to logging match energy onto RFID tags on the battery, easily readable with your phone.

posts.name: Michael Anderson
posts.cooked: That seems like an impressive solution.  How is the data entered into the tag?

Adding some sources to your excellent current-rating information:

The screenshot is from the Anderson SB50 connector datasheet . Also in this document, on page 3 of the .pdf, are charts of temperature performance.

image 792×755 104 KB

image 792×755 104 KB

image 792×755 104 KB

Anderson also has a very nice technical note on how to read / interpret these charts .

The different temperature ratings in the datasheet are with respect to different standards. I found an old copy of the UL 1977 standard , which describes testing with constant current for 4 hours to ensure that the connector does not exceed the temperature rating of any of the insulators in the connector, and that it can break 150% of the rated current at least 50 times. (Unfortunately I don’t have $400 to read the latest version of the UL standard, but these things usually only get minor revisions over the years.)

I couldn’t easily find the relevant CSA standard ( their website seems to be down at the moment), but Anderson’s technical note describes it as only allowing a 30°C temperature rise above the ambient temperature of 25°C, rather than however much the insulators are rated to take.

All of this is to say that, under most FRC circumstances, it is fine to put a lot more than 50 amps through an Anderson SB50 connector – 50 amps is just the most conservative rating, which is okay under pretty much all circumstances.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: USB RFID reader, run by the vision computer, as far as I understand.  Still a work in progress…

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I once hooked a SB50 pair to a spot welder to “condition” the terminals and see if a good hit of current made the resistance lower.  The answer was “no”, but the wires jumping due to the current/magnetic forces was cool!

posts.name: Michael Anderson
posts.cooked: I may circle back to you on this.  Interesting
